newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Jan-May new vehicle sales rise 4.8 pct.
newsitem.headline: Australian Jan-May new vehicle sales rise 4.8 pct.

text.p: Australian new vehicle sales rose by 4.8 percent or 12,608 vehicles in the first five months of calendar 1997, the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries (FCAI) said on Friday.
Year-to-date sales totalled 274,599 compared with 261,991 a year ago.

In the month of May, new vehicle sales rose by 5.7 percent against their April level but fell 1.0 percent compared with May last year. Sales totalled 59,498 in May against 56,284 in April and 60,073 a year ago.
FCAI said it had retained its calendar 1997 sales forecast at 640,000.
In May, the passenger vehicle market fell by 2.7 percent over the same month last year, but was 3.88 percent up on April.
Truck sales rose 4.42 percent from May last year.
Year-to-date, the total passenger vehicle market was up by 6,991 or 3.5 percent due to the continued strength in the small car segment, which rose by 22.2 percent.
FCAI also said there were solid year-to-date performances in the sports car sector which rose 1,403 or 40.1 percent, and the luxury car segment which was up by 1,554 or 29.1 percent.

It said there was a polarisation evident in the passenger market with the medium car sector falling 20.8 percent or 4,684 in the first five months to May, the upper medium segment falling 2,479 or 3.1 percent and the light car segment down 1.3 percent or 260.

Ford Motor Co was the market leader in May with a market share of 19.7 percent and also holds the top spot for the year-to-date with a market share of 18.9 percent. This was down on the 20.0 percent held in the first five months of 1996.
In second place was General Motors Corp with a 17.7 ercent market share in May, followed by Toyota Motor Corp with 16.9 percent.
